Lucid9 is an interactive visual novel with characters and humor that will surpass any visual novel expectations you may have from other games. ++ART
Now I'm not an art major or anything but the art in this game is fantastic. The art style isn't too extravagant. Some backgrounds are reused for a few places but overall there is quite a large amount of unique pieces. 8/10

++LENGTH
Personally I got around a solid 10 hours of gameplay for my first playthrough. This is with me not using the skip tool, reading 95% of the dialogue (was a bit late a night). I've also spent about 2 hours just going back and choosing different options at different moments just to experience it all. Plus it would be good to mention that there ARE NO MICROTRANSACTIONS WHATSOEVER in order to increase game length, so you get this wonderful experience without digging into your steam wallet/paypal. 9.5/10

+STORY
There is a surprising amount of depth and storyline to this free gem of a game. I won't go into details for the sake of saying that YOU NEED TO PLAY THIS GAME FOR YOURSELF. I found myself cheering and stunned at some moments of this game.

HOWEVER
The game does leave off with a cliffhanger that gave me mixed feelings. It's nice to know that there'll be another game but at the same time I feel like some people will like the ending to this game a lot more than others. Other than that the only real bashful thing I have to say about this game is that a lot of the decisions you make early on won't effect the end outcome (TO MY LIMITED KNOWLEGE, WILL UPDATE THIS REVIEW IF I FIND OUT MORE). A lot of the really important decisions come at the end, and I even had to look up a guide to get the ending I wanted. 7/10 for story.

You can really tell that the team involved poured their hearts and souls into the creation of this visual novel, and I have nothing but respect for them.

I've REALLY enjoyed my experience with this game, and I'm so excited for the voice acting patch next year. reviewText:
I hate slice of life. I love mysteries. You know what I really hate? How VN authors always shove slice of life into mystery stories. The slice of life just inevitably clashes with the heavier tone of a good mystery and lessens the suspense. At least, I used to think that such pitfalls were inevitable before reading Lucid9.

Lucid9 takes a while to really get going on the mystery side, instead opting to be predominately lighthearted for the first several hours. Surprisingly though, that actually plays well into the storytelling. In a VN like G-Senjou no Maou, the slice of life scenes, while fun and enjoyable in a vacuum, feel out of place in the larger context of the story. Going from intense crime solving and battles of wits to unconsequential goofy high school funtimes doesn't always work so well.

However, Lucid9's brilliantly written slice of life (whose brilliance is largely due to hilarious, snappy dialogue) provides some excellent build-up that heightens the impact of the mystery plot later on. When a character is in danger, you actually care. When it comes time to solve the mystery, you really won't want to point fingers at any of the great characters you've come to love. What I'm getting at here is that the slice of life segments do a great job at creating a cast of likable and believable characters that all tie into the plot very nicely.

Of course, even if the slice of life half of the story is strong, the mystery needs to also be good. And it is! The entire story is peppered with subtle foreshadowing that is hidden in plain sight to keep the mystery fair" to solve

PHEW. WHAT A ROLLERCOASTER. sjflkaj;s

All I could think about this week was Lucid9. I recommended it to everyone I knew who liked the VN genre (and would listen to my ramblings), and have gotten at least one poor soul hooked on this game. I wish more people would listen, though, because this masterpiece deserves so, so, so much more love and attention. <3

I finished it just a few minutes ago, and I am worn out. This game managed to dig through my internal organs, squish them into mush, and leave me to stew here with a broken heart and a liver halfway up my chest. Not a great situation, but somehow... really, really satisfying. I feel like I need a day of napping just to recuperate from the up-and-down emotions I felt throughout my playthrough of this game. I've laughed, felt accomplished (acing that history quiz without once googling anything made me so proud!), been shocked, terrified, disgusted, sad, and extremely affected. Lucid9 manages to deliver a story so well paced and written that it rivals many of the other costly games I've played. I honestly can't believe this gem is free; I would pay for it in a heartbeat, although I must say that it was the price tag that drew me to pick it up in the first place.

Anyway, there's something for everyone in this VN, especially for those who are fans of other VNs, manga, anime, and the like. I'm not a massive enthusiast, and usually can't stand just sitting and clicking, but the story is so engaging that you'll find yourself hard-pressed to close the game and go to bed. With the variety of romance routes, cute girls (and boys), self-referential humour, satire, and lots of tearjerking kmoments, I guarantee something will get to you. The music and art is pretty neat, too, and the assets are arranged in a way that definitely maximises the writing's impact.

* - Side Note: The UI in this game is absolutely gorgeous as well. I'm so glad it was something that was seriously considered in the development, because I hate outdated/clunky menus. Lucid9's everything is so clean and minimal, and I can't thank the devs enough for that, hahaha.

And what's more -- love it or hate it, you might as well try it. The developers are angels, honestly, because there's nothing you need to give to play this beautiful game besides your time. And I'm sure it'll be well spent.

Great work all around, Fallen Snow Studios -- I can't wait to play episode 2. :D

You know that feeling when you finish a really good series or book, and you have nothing to do with your life?

That's exactly what I felt.

Normally, it would take me several episodes to get me hooked on a series or lots of chapters in a book. For Lucid9, however...

It took 6 minutes.

I started playing at 10:00pm, I randomly checked the steam market and saw this. It took a short while to download, so I played it at 10:20.

I didn't read what it was about, I saw anime-styled characters and a school, and I thought it was just a slice of life kind of thing. I thought it would just be a funny game where I didn't have much of an attachment to the characters.

After the initial six minutes of getting hooked, I kept playing and didn't keep track of the time. Played until 12:50 AM and went to sleep.

The next day I played straight for 4 hours. It's very easy to binge.

It left me in shock, a game where I was experiencing high school in a First World Metropolis? I normally think slice of life's are cheesy, but for some reason this was an emotional rollercoaster unlike some Visual Novels.

The characters had similar characteristics to many of my friends, I could literally match them to some of the characters.

The dialogue felt real, it felt as if this wasn't written and it felt as if real people had said it.

The soundtrack was composed of the same songs, but man oh man they are perfect for the situations they're in. I couldn't have picked better for the scenes.

The art style may throw those people who think that being a weeaboo is just liking the art off but the art was amazing and I loved it.

The story is truly amazing, it was easy to understand, was stressful and entertaining, and put me through several stages of emotion.

I went from happy, to sad, to happy, to sad, to even sadder, to nearly crying...

Being that I already tried to post this earlier, but failed due to Steam being a butt, I'll keep it short.

Background: Originally, I approached the creative team behind Lucid9 to inquire about potential voice acting, and despite being skeptical at first, I managed to convince the team to allow my team to provide them with such, further bringing the characters to life. We have currently recorded all of day 1 and will resume day 2 sometime this month. Note: I did not read the entirety of the script prior to recording as I wanted the full experience by actually playing the game.

Story: Short and simple. I'm a picky person in regards to storytelling and Lucid9 managed to be one of those stories that did exactly what I wanted and captured me. Smooth writing with clear and concise details and a plot that seems very light-hearted but with a brutal twist as you near the end. Some minor grammar, punctuation etc errors, but that's just a nitpick. Basically, Lucid9's story and storytelling were both captivating and effective.

Characters: Typical anime tropes with tsunderes, quirky comic reliefs, sarcastic know it alls and more, but with heavy background that isn't explicitly described in detail. I presume they are waiting until post common route to get into individual routes which would more then likely have detailed backgrounds of each character. Still. The characters and their interactions with each other were both colorful and dynamic, assuring my growing love for them.

Art: Need I say more then beautiful? It is very Key-esque, and probably even Key inspired. Very detailed and colorful.

Music: Always catchy for me. Music is something that is paramount to a good game, movie, anime, etc. This game had music that kept me humming along whenever one I really liked popped up.

Verdict: 9/10 Frankly, Lucid9 is one of the best OELVN's I've played, which is unfortunately not many and I recommend it to everyone. It even managed to keep me awake a full night with no sleep. That should tell you something. reviewText:
Long Story Short: A very good free visual novel. Better than a lot of paid visual novels on steam right now. The first part of a bigger story that manages to resolve its central plot line. If you like visual novels, give it a shot.

Story

Lucid9 follows Yama Ishimoto, a cynical carefree high student of a prestigious high school in 2018 Japan. All is fine with the world, except  it is swiftly shown that students are going missing. The opening scene quickly shows there's a serial killer involved and the central mystery is established.

Inciting Incident is the first part of a larger story and, as such, the romance aspect one may come to expect from visual novels isn't especially present yet. Instead, much of the plot is focused on solving the mystery presented early on, and I believe it has done a good job for this. Yama is neither a super genius or a detective so most of the time he isn't actively trying to solve the puzzle, but the reader, if they stay focused and pay attention, are provided with plenty of clues disguise as typical high school slice-of-life scenes. Having been through the story already, I will say that I believe the mystery is completely fair and can be solved with the information provided directly to the reader.

Characters

Along side the mystery plot are the characters. Yama is quickly shown to be rude, self-centered, snarky and judgemental, most likely far from the expected badass/all-loving/idealistic protagonist one may come to expect from most visual novels. A large number of visual novels will focus on developing the heroines rather than the protagonist and it's refreshing to see a visual novel protagonist with potential for character developments. That said, while it is nice to see someone who's not a straight-up nice guy protagonist, Yama can sometimes be a huge unreasonable, judgemental and unapologetic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. So while it's good that the character has a lot of room for development (and he does develop here), Yama can also be very hard to stomach, especially when he gets away with being a huge prick to people who are not his friends. This being a first part of a bigger story however means there's still plenty of time for him to grow out of that, something I look forward to seeing.

Then we have the five heroines: Rui, (blatant) tsundere childhood friend, Elizabeth, high-and-mighty straight-laced overachiever, Akira, bubbly and over-energetic friend, Misaki, quirky and carefree childhood friend and Airi, weird emotionless and literal-minded bullied kid. If you're familiar with visual novels or just anime in general, they will all sound incredibly archetypical. Fortunately, the writing proved to be much better than I initially anticipated, and the girls all have hidden depths that, so far, manages to be believable as well as surprising and avoided being broken birds for the protagonist to fix and woo. The same can also be said to the two male friends: Yahiko, the cheerful idiot, and Masato, the hot-headed stubborn musclehead. It is this unexpected depth that especially impressed me and moved me from eye-rolling at the early parts of the plot to being fully invested in the mystery and development of the characters. That said, it should also be mentioned that a lot of the early dialogues, while not indicative of the strength of the writing, can be so filled with constant sarcasm, snarks and wackiness that they can get very insufferable very quickly. Once you get pass that however, there's a lot to love here and the writing as a whole will prove to be much better than the early stages would suggest.

Gameplay

Lucid9 is a visual novel and come with the sort of gameplay (or whatever you choose to call it) one would expect from the genre. Choices are present. Some are clearly there to let you earn points" with the respective heroines

reviewText:
TL; DR Highly enjoyed + recommended, and it's free so it can't hurt to try it out anyway.
Aside from an attention-grabbing mysterious prologue about a psychopathic murderer, Lucid9: Inciting Incident starts off as what may seem like a typical high school slice of life RomCom. Set in the near future of 2018, you have your highly intelligent but seemingly lazy, cynical and snarky male protagonist. You also have the female childhood friend love interest who stuck up for him in the past, helped him get through some past trauma and essentially stick to him like glue his entire life, whilst never actually confessing to him. You even have childhood friend number two, the female transfer student, and let's not forget the protagonist's male allies either;  the apparently aloof, warm-hearted and kind womanizing support character number 1, and support character number 2, the jock (although in his defence his grades are superb). Oh and of course the first female childhood friend has a female friend support character trying to match make the protagonist despite also having feel-
Ok, so you get the idea. As one of the characters say, the protagonist's school life seems like the perfect set up for a 'really crap anime'.
Thankfully, it is anything but.
Despite the initial setup that might send warning signs of a 'cliche', 'boring' or 'generic' environment, the witty dialogue, references, memes and humorous character chemistry create a thoroughly entertaining and amusing experience. The dialogue is spectacular, which is probably partially due to the fact this is an original English story, but to the writers' credit, I'm still surprised by how good the dialogue is.  As you can probably tell, I really enjoyed this section of the game; the protagonist's snarky attitude reminded me of Yuuji from Grisaia with his internal dialogues, and the cutesy art and music meshed together pretty well to create a fun slice of life RomCom.
Except, of course, that's not what this VN is about. Or at least that's not the main driving force behind the plot. Even throughout this happy-go-lucky style of plot, there is an undercurrent of a darker, more mysterious and dangerous force at work, just in case you didn't notice from the store page screaming murder and mystery at you. And this is where the story really picks up and becomes more about the mystery, murder and detective aspect rather than the high school life of an ordinary student. We see more about the tragic past of the protagonist and his friends, and more foreboding of the murderer's intentions with the chilling music emphasizing the danger as we attempt to deduce who it is. However,  despite the transition into the faster paced plot driven 2nd half of the VN, the focus of the original story is never lost. That is to say, even with all the events in the plot building up climatically to the final showdown, there is always a focus on the main character, his relationships, his past and how he'll change for the better, which I think is a pretty good thing. Because if I had to pick one aspect of the game as a whole that I like the most I'd have to say the characters. Despite what I said about them coming off as generic and cliche at the start of the game, they develop and become fleshed-out, and they seem, believe it or not, human. Which is actually a big deal. They become relatable and pretty damn loveable, which is why they're my favourite part of Lucid9.
What impresses me the most though is the fact that this is done without any monetary support. To be frank, I was expecting the lack of monetary funding to result in compromises whether it be in the technical elements like the settings/menu options or in the quality of the writing/art/music. But the art style fits the tone, the UI is polished and almost 40 tracks accompany the novel throughout, from the 'nostalgic emotional memory' feel to the 'imminent boss fight' feel, which really does enhance the effect of whatever may be going in the story at that time. For me, I usually place a lot more importance on the writing and art than anything else, but when all the other bits and pieces work, even I can appreciate what a difference they make to the overall quality.
Another technical element worth highlighting is the choice system, and the interactive aspect of the game in general. Some of the choices give access to new comedic scenes, CG arts or achievements but some of the others are more serious, dictating whether you reach the bad or 'true/good' end. I think a nice balance between difficulty and importance is achieved as a result, because it's pretty easy to either create meaningless choices or give options to a problem that is too tedious to solve by mistake. The few logic puzzles are an enjoyable aspect as they change the pace a bit and force you to think, but at the same time they're definitely accessible, and if you choose the wrong answer or the joke answer you're easily forgiven too. I'm eager to see more of them in the future since I suspect they will become more common in the individual heroine routes when the fundamental mystery plot is actually revealed.
I suppose the one gripe I have is that a technical feature that I think could be implemented is missing; a skip to the next choice feature, mostly for replaying + achievement/cg hunting. Personally I've never been that much of an achievement collector but I admit I get curious if I see a bunch of hidden achievements and missing CG art, enough to want to select the choices I didn't choose last time and see what happens. A skip to the next choice feature would help in that regard, rather than just using the ordinary skip function whilst making a lot of save points at all the choices.
Overall though, I'm pretty damn impressed by Lucid9. I'll definitely be looking forward to both the voice patch and the heroine route patch, since this is only the beginning after all. This is easily in my top 6 VNs, and to be honest, if you've gotten this far in the review and still aren't sure whether to try it or not, just do it. It's free after all.

But Lucid9 is an amazing story, and I feel the need to say something. Both so that other people might pick up the experience, and as I way of showing the developers appreciation for a wonderful, free experience.

When you get into Lucidy9, you'll find yourself pointing fingers at the characters, seeking out hints behind the mystery, and all the while pushing your character into the arms of your chosen waifu and aborsbing yourself in the drama, past, and daily life of the main character Yama.
This VN easily plays as a psychological mystery horror, romance, comedy, and still manages to tie all of its many characteristics rather perfectly.
When you finish this VN, you'll feel joy, you'll feel truimph, and ultimately, you'll feel sadness.

If you want to feel the familiar feels of a good book, or vn, or anime, or whatever stimulates your feels, this is a very good option.

reviewText:
Lucid9, where to start with this gem?

I really don't know what I was expecting when I installed this game. But what I recieved was more then I've expected.

Honestly after playing this game, like most other people, I agree that I would have payed for this game. The fact that a game that so thought out and hard worked on is free, honestly leaves me slightly upset. In fact I would've rather spent $60 on this game then any other game I've ever bought in my 12 years of gaming, regardless of the fact that it is 'only' a visual novel.

But more about the game:

The first thing that comes to mind is how masterfully fluid the game felt. The first bit everthing was a blur, not paying much attention to the subtle things that all came back when it mattered. But as I played longer and felt myself getting more immersed, it was hard not to remember everthing. I realized everything I did, learned and 'saw' was more important then I possibly could have imagined. But in the end I feel like I did more than play a game.

For Example, meeting multipe indepth characters that not only I could relate to, but could empathize with. I not only meet and felt for these charaters but came to care for them, which is rare to find in games now-a-adays. Just throwing people into a game and telling some background on them doesn't mean there's a connection. How quickly the characters in this game got to me was amazing.

I also personally love the music. The way every scene has a specific piece and how it set the mood for who's talking or what's about to happen. There isn't much else to say about it other that.

But to sum up the game, it's one I won't be forgetting, in a good way. I haven't played my other visual novels but I feel it was that opened me up more to the catagory. And I have this game to thank for the many, many more VNs I see myself playing in the future.

If you haven't played the game and want to, I highly suggest not looking at this next comment. You have bee warned!!!
P.S. I am NOT happy about the final death, RIP Rue, you will be remembered.

P.S.S. As if I haven't played enough, I now await for the release of the Voiced version so I can relive the experience.

I wrote a really in-depth and long review which I realized probably would bore people. So now short and sweet.

Story:
Never a dull moment. And I have the attention span of a yogurt bottle (does yogurt have attention?). Don't be fooled by what it appears to be at first- a simple slice-of-life visual novel with plenty of wit and and humor. It's not. Very deep and by the time the ending came I was so invested that the ending made me feel sick to my stomach (and I don't get queezy with blood; it was out of sheer rage/sadness at what happened).

Characters:
They may appear stereotypical but they're not. No, not at all. Each are unique and interesting in their own way.

Art:
I don't know anything about art, but to me, it was really high-quality.

Music:
I typically don't notice the music as much as i do the other features. This one I did. They all fit the scenes perfectly and definitely helped raise my stress during the more intense scenes (and of course helped me laugh during the comedic scenes). I wouldn't mind paying some money for future DLC which includes the soundtrack (though the complete OST is on Youtube).

Overall:
Lucid9 definitely could have cost around $10 and it still would have been worth it. You can tell the effort put into this marvelous game in every aspect as you play through it. Even if you're not a fan of visual novels or even anime, I highly recommend playing this. I look forward to the next installment (and the voice acting patch next year; gives me a good excuse to re-read it).

This game is amazing. I love visual novels, but I'm more prone to play the dating style ones instead of mystery and action. This game has changed that for me. Almost constantly, I was either on the edge of my seat in suspense or laughing so hard I could barely breath. Yama is a breath of fresh air as well as a main character, branching away from the oblivous boy who becomes a man later on, to a wisecrack that tries to crawl away from his depression. Plus, the game is free, so check it out!

The main character and some of his friends are initially quite hard to like, but you do warm up to them some, after a while.

As far as EVNs go, the writing is definitely a cut above average, with few errors (not none, but there's a lot of wordage), and the mystery is well-developed, and handled competently.

The climax is something of a tricky labyrinth of bad-ends, with little signposting - though the bad ends themselves sometimes give some clues. I feel that area could have been done a bit better, and the hard-to-thread web of choices during it does suck some of the immediacy out of the climax.

Content includes some pretty horrifying material, at times - which is further thrown into contrast by the lighter, more everyday scenes. That contrast serves to increase the impact. If you've a sensitive disposition, you should take care to pace yourself some.

While this is a first part, and not a whole, story progression is solid. Think of it as the first season of a TV series. Arcs are started and completed, but there's still more to carry on with at the end.

All in all, though, an excellent effort that should keep you going for a dozen hours, at minimum.

I wrote a really in-depth and long review which I realized probably would bore people. So now short and sweet.

Story:
Never a dull moment. And I have the attention span of a yogurt bottle (does yogurt have attention?). Don't be fooled by what it appears to be at first- a simple slice-of-life visual novel with plenty of wit and and humor. It's not. Very deep and by the time the ending came I was so invested that the ending made me feel sick to my stomach (and I don't get queezy with blood; it was out of sheer rage/sadness at what happened).

Characters:
They may appear stereotypical but they're not. No, not at all. Each are unique and interesting in their own way.

Art:
I don't know anything about art, but to me, it was really high-quality.

Music:
I typically don't notice the music as much as i do the other features. This one I did. They all fit the scenes perfectly and definitely helped raise my stress during the more intense scenes (and of course helped me laugh during the comedic scenes). I wouldn't mind paying some money for future DLC which includes the soundtrack (though the complete OST is on Youtube).

Overall:
Lucid9 definitely could have cost around $10 and it still would have been worth it. You can tell the effort put into this marvelous game in every aspect as you play through it. Even if you're not a fan of visual novels or even anime, I highly recommend playing this. I look forward to the next installment (and the voice acting patch next year; gives me a good excuse to re-read it).

This in-depth review is as spoiler free as possible.

PLOT: 10/10
The first few minutes of the game make you feel like this will be your average visual novel where you choose between different girls and end up dating one of them at the end. Just your normal fluffy waifu simulator. But as the story progresses, the plot goes deeper than you would think.

Even though I was enjoying the light theme of the story at the beginning, I almost stopped playing because I thought that it would only go up to that. Boy, was I glad I didn't stop. This VN is intense, with you trying to make ends meet in your mind as to what is actually happening. If you're reading this, I advise you NOT TO STOP just a few hours in. You won't be able to grasp how well written this story is. But then again, if you're only looking for that fluffy otome style VN, maybe you should turn away.

CHARACTERS: 10/10
I loved the characters in this game. VNs usually only focus on the main girl you are aiming for. This game, on the other hand, lets you get to know all of the characters fairly, as long as you take the time to hang out with them of course. Each character has their own personalities and quirks that make them different from one another. Your relationships with them span from typical childhood friend to idiotic-but-lovable classmate, making your interactions with each of them different.

WRITING: 9/10
The writing was exquisite. Each character also had their own way of speaking and texting, with varying degrees in their vocabularies. I also loved the details put into this game. By the time you reach the climax, those minor details that you brushed off as insignificant all come flooding back. Those minor bits of foreshadowing all clump together to paint the entire picture. Just lovely.

ART: 8/10
It's your typical anime styled visual novel. It's clean, and the variety of expressions on the characters were good. The backgrounds were pretty as well. The small details like the characters zooming in when speaking worked really well.

MUSIC: 8/10
The background music really ties the feel of the scenes together. It's a great way to set the mood. Happy music for light-hearted scenes, and more solemn music for the more serious parts. Here's hoping that the future voice acting patch helps bring everything together as well.

OVERALL: 9/10
Very enjoyable, and easy to get hooked on. I can proudly say that my hours spent playing this VN have not gone to waste, especially for a free game. If you have even just a few hours of spare time, I highly recommend giving this game a shot.
P.S. I enjoyed the various easter eggs and shoutouts to different games. It made me feel that much closer to the characters.

I have been enjoying this game very much. This is the third Visual Novel I've played recently. I had stayed away from them for some reason, but now I'm glad I actually took the time to check them out. What I like about this game are the choices. Some Visual Novels won't give you any and some of the others that do, their choices mean little. That's why I've stayed away from these games. But the choices in this game matter. You can't get every achievement in one playthrough which is good, too. It'd be boring if you could gain it all at once. I like how different things happen depending on your choice and what you do.

I enjoyed the story of the game as well. It was confusing when points of view shifted at first, but I understood it once I looked at the corner of my screen and saw the different color. A nice murder mystery with romantic and psychologic elements in it... Overall a great story.

If I had one bad thing about it, though... I was a little sad at the ending. Not in a bad way. It was a good ending, it's just... Yeah, I didn't want it to end like that. I don't believe I have ever, in my entire life, experienced a story as masterfully written as this. The story, the dialogue, the characters... it's all perfect. For a relatively short visual novel, it's amazing how the writers were able to flesh out every character and give them unique depth, unlike two-dimensional characters based off common anime tropes in games such as Danganronpa and Fire Emblem. The game took me about 6 hours for my first playthrough, but it was too good not to play more than once. And it was definitely worth it; playing through the game a second, I understood what was going on a lot better, picked up on new details I'd missed before, and chose different options to see other scenes.

For a visual novel, Lucid9: Inciting Incident is near flawless. There are a few minor flaws, one being a pacing issue at a certain point in the game, and the other being a sudden shift in how the game works at the end, which could easily frustrate players if they haven't been keeping multiple copies of their save files (which I advise you to do if you play this game).

But apart from those, Lucid9 is a spectacular game, and I must applaud the amazing people who managed to make everything for this game, including the overarching story, the dialogue, the art, and the fantastic music. I would definitely recommend this to anyone who even remotely enjoys a good story.
